siteProductLine.name: Cinturato P7 All Season

siteProductBrand.pdpPageBrandAboutInfo: Based in Milan, Italy, Pirelli was founded in 1872 and is the fifth largest tire manufacturer in the World. Pirelli's first tires were introduced in 1901, and today they can be found on many of today's most powerful vehicles such as Bentleys, Ferraris, Lamborghinis, and Porsches in addition to Formula 1 and other racing cars. Pirelli tires typically feature the latest innovations, such as Run-Flat technology and Pirelli's Noise Cancelling System.

pdpPageBrandHighlights.description: Tires designed and engineered to meet your vehicle’s specific needs.
pdpPageBrandHighlights.title: The “Perfect fit”

pdpPageBrandHighlights.description: State-of-the-art technology for all tire types, passenger or SUV.
pdpPageBrandHighlights.title: Innovation

siteProductLine.overview:
An all-season tire, the Cinturato P7 All Season is designed for use on performance vehicles and offers drivers strong performance and handling in wet and dry conditions.

Features & Benefits
  • All-season tread
  • Black sidewall
  • Optimized tread design reduces noise to give drivers a comfortable ride
siteProductLine.secondaryDescription: Finding a set of tires that are built to perform year-round is a must for most drivers, and Pirelli designed to Cinturato P7 All Season with these drivers in mind. An innovative tread pattern and four wide grooves work to evacuate water to increase performance on wet roads, and the Cinturato P7 All Season's optimized tread design lowers internal noises to improve ride comfort. Built with robust tread elements to give drivers excellent steering response in any weather condition, the Cinturato P7 All Season is commonly used by drivers of the Alfa Romeo Giulia, Audi A3, BMW 3-Series, Cadillac CTS, Fiat 500, Jaguar XE, Lincoln MKS, Mercedes B Class, Mini Paceman, Porsche Panamera, Volkswagen Golf, and Volvo S60.

siteProductSpecs.name: Category
siteProductSpecs.description: Like  their name suggest, all season tires are designed to give drivers performance year-round. All-season tires often provide strong performance in dry and wet conditions, and suitable traction and grip in wintery weather.

siteProductSpecs.name: Vehicle
siteProductSpecs.description: Passenger tires are some of the most common tires you'll find on the roads today, and frequently used on coupes, sedans, hatchbacks, minivans, and other passenger vehicles. Passenger tires are available in a wide variety of types, such as all-season, winter, and ultra-high-performance.

siteProductSpecs.name: Mileage Warranty
siteProductSpecs.description: This product is not covered by a manufacturer’s treadlife warranty.

siteProductSpecs.name: Load Index
siteProductSpecs.description: The maximum carrying capacity for a tire determined by the manufacturer.

siteProductSpecs.name: Max Speed
siteProductSpecs.description: Maximum speed capability to safely carry a load for an extended period of time.

siteProductSpecs.name: Load Range
siteProductSpecs.description: The maximum load carrying strength at the specified inflation pressure, also known as ply rating.

siteProductSpecs.name: Sidewall
siteProductSpecs.description: The side of the tire between the tread and rim, with cosmetic branding as well as information about the tire including manufacturer, model, size, etc.

siteProductSpecs.name: UTQG
siteProductSpecs.description: Standards that measure treadwear, temperature resistance and traction, example: "640 A A".  The 640 is the treadwear test and it lasted 6.4 times longer than the comparison tire tested against.  The first "A" is the traction rating using straight-line wet traction on test surfaces (see information tables tab) and the second "A" is the temperature rating by testing operation at high speeds without heat-related failure (see information tables tab).

siteProductSpecs.name: Wet Traction
siteProductSpecs.description: Wet Traction is a piece of the UTQG for example if  UTQG is: 500 AA A, the wet traction piece is the second piece, the "AA".

siteProductSpecs.name: Tread Depth
siteProductSpecs.description: Measured in 32nds of an inch, this metric shows how much tread life is left on a tire, with the tire's traction & stopping capabilities greatly diminished at 4/32nds and less. Tire manufacturers include "tire wear bars" at 2/32nds to indicate when your tire is worn out.

siteProductSpecs.name: Inflation Pressure
siteProductSpecs.description: The highest inflation pressure (measured in pounds of force per square inch, PSI) the tire is designed to contain, and should only be used when called for by the vehicle placard.

siteProductSpecs.name: Part Number
siteProductSpecs.description: An identifier of a particular tire line and size combination assigned by the tire manufacturer.

siteProductSpecs.name: Tread Design
siteProductSpecs.description: Tread design (or tread pattern) can affect handling, traction & noise for different driving styles & road conditions.

siteProductSpecs.name: Section Width
siteProductSpecs.description: The measurement of width from a tires inner sidewall to the outer sidewall.

siteProductSpecs.name: Rim Range
siteProductSpecs.description: The range of widths the rim of the vehicle can be for this tire to be safely mounted on.

siteProductSpecs.name: Overall Diameter
siteProductSpecs.description: The diameter of a tire that is inflated without any load applied.

image.altText: Car Driving on Highway in Rainy Weather

header.title: All Season tires
header.body:
# All Season tires
Like their name suggests, all season tires are designed to perform year-round and specifically excel in dry, wet, and winter weather conditions.

All season tires are the most common tire type on the road today, and can be found on coupes, sedans, minivans, CUVs, SUVs, and light trucks. All-season tires are made by all of the most prominent tire manufacturers including, but not limited to [Goodyear](https://simpletire.com/brands/goodyear-tires/categories/all-season), [Pirelli](https://simpletire.com/brands/pirelli-tires/categories/all-season), [Michelin](https://simpletire.com/brands/michelin-tires/categories/all-season), [Firestone](https://simpletire.com/brands/firestone-tires/categories/all-season), [Venezia](https://simpletire.com/brands/venezia-tires/categories/all-season) and [Nokian](https://simpletire.com/brands/nokian-tires/categories/all-season).

If you're looking to buy a set of all-season tires online then you've come to the right place, as SimpleTire has thousands of great all-season tires that can meet your driving needs and budget.

[All season tire reviews](https://simpletire.com/categories/all-season-tires/reviews)

articleList.description: All-season tires are found on most cars, so it can be hard to find the best ones. Here are SimpleTire’s picks of the Best All Season Tires for 2023.
articleList.title: Best All Season Tires for 2023

articleList.description: Learn how all season tires work, how they compare to summer and winter tires, and when they're best suited for you as a driver.
articleList.title: All-season tires: How they work & when you need them

siteProductVisualizationInsightList.title: Great Wet Traction
siteProductVisualizationInsightList.sliderInfoModalContent:
This tire has great wet traction, which means that drivers should 
                            expect strong grip on wet roads. As a general rule of thumb, traction can vary based on driving 
                            and maintenance habits and road conditions.

siteProductVisualizationInsightList.title: Great Handling
siteProductVisualizationInsightList.sliderInfoModalContent:
This tire has a great speed rating, which means it can safely handle 
                            speeds between 130mph and 149mph without the risk of failure. As a general rule of thumb, 
                            posted speed limits should always be followed and proper tire maintenance and 
                            rotation can help prevent failure.
